did.head: Collection Summary

langmaterial.label: Language
langmaterial.language: English, with some French and German

descriptivenote.p: Collection material in English, with some French and German

did.abstract: Economist, diplomat and humanitarian. Correspondence, journals, minutes, speeches, statements, scrapbooks, memoranda, news clippings, printed matter, photographs, and other material relating mainly to Davis's participation between the world wars in international conferences on peace, disamament, and international monetary matters.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

corpname.part: Allied and Associated Powers (1914-1920). Supreme Economic Council.
Conference for the Reduction and Limitation of Armaments (1932-1934 : Geneva, Switzerland)
Monetary and Economic Conference (1933 : London, England)

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The papers of Norman H. Davis, economist and diplomat, were given to the Library of Congress in 1953, 1958, 1964, and 1984 by the Council on Foreign Relations. Priscilla Kellert gave a further addition to the collection in 2007.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The papers of Norman H. Davis were arranged and described by staff in 1953. The collection was expanded and revised by Russell Smith in 1956, Robert A. Land in 1957, Grover Batts in 1958, David Mathisen in 1985, and Joseph K. Brooks in 2012.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: The status of copyright in the unpublished writings of Norman H. Davis is governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.).

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The papers of Norman H. Davis are open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Manuscript Reading Room prior to visiting. Many collections are stored off-site and advance notice is needed to retrieve these items for research use.

accessrestrict.head: Security Classified Documents
accessrestrict.p: Government regulations control the use of security classified material in this collection. Manuscript Division staff can furnish information concerning access to and use of classified materials.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Container number, Norman H. Davis Papers, Manuscript Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The papers of diplomat and economist Norman Hezekiah Davis (1878-1944) span the years 1898-1979 with the bulk of the material concentrated between 1915 and 1944. In 1902 Davis began his business career in Cuba where he organized the Trust Company of Cuba. He commenced a public career in 1917 and served in four presidential administrations consulting on international finance at the Department of Treasury, the Department of State, and international conferences and committees during World War I and the the interwar period. Davis was chairman of the of the American Red Cross from 1938 to his death in 1944.

The papers are organized into seven series: Correspondence and Other Papers , Printed Matter , Addition I , Addition II , Addition III , Oversize , and Classified . The Correspondence and Other Papers series consists of correspondence, diaries, journals, minutes, addresses, statements, scrapbooks, memoranda, clippings, printed matter, photographs, and other papers relating chiefly to Davisâ€™s services as a participant in international conferences and commissions on peace, disarmament, monetary matters and as a financial and economic consultant. The series includes material on conferences and organizations including the Supreme Economic Council of the Allied and Associated Powers (1914-1920), the Armistice, Paris Peace Conference (1919), International Economic Conference (Geneva, 1927), League of Nations, Limitation of Arms Conference (Geneva, 1932-1934), Monetary and Economic Conference (London, 1933), London Naval Conference (1935-1936), the Brussels Nine-Power Conference (1937), and other conferences and organizations. Correspondents include Herbert Hoover, Viscount Robert Gascoyne-Cecil, Cecil of Chelwood, Cordell Hull, Thomas W. Lamont, and Frank A. Vanderlip.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Papers
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in seven series:

scopecontent.p: Letters sent and received, memoranda, copies of statements and addresses, journals, minutes, addresses, statements, scrapbooks, memoranda, clippings, printed matter, photographs, and miscellaneous material.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by name of person, organization, or subject. There is some arrangement of dossiers within larger subjects such as the Supreme Economic Council, but many subject groups are wholly unarranged.
